I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Many countries in East and South Asia are intensifying efforts at regional economic 
cooperation and integration.1 A number of initiatives for economic cooperation within the region 
have either come into force in recent years or are in various stages of negotiation.2  Most of the 
cooperation agreements are among countries within the subregions of East Asia and South 
Asia.3 However, linkages between the two subregions are growing, with the rising importance of 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  India  in  the  world  economy,  and  against  the 
backdrop of India’s “Look East” policy initiated in 1991. 
 
2.  An  example  of  agreements  between  East  and  South  Asian  countries  is  the 
Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement between India and Singapore, which came 
into effect in 2005. India has also signed framework agreements on comprehensive economic 
cooperation with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and a free trade area 
with Thailand, both of which are under negotiation. The Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-
Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC)4 is also negotiating its framework 
agreement on a free trade area. PRC-India and PRC-Pakistan free trade agreements have 
been proposed and framework agreements are under negotiation. The Bangkok Agreement is 
another preferential trading agreement among Bangladesh, PRC, India, Korea, Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and Sri Lanka. In addition to cooperation agreements among 
themselves, East and South Asian countries are also pursuing similar relationships with other 
countries in Asia and Pacific region and in other regions. 
 
3.  The proliferation of bilateral agreements to enhance economic cooperation within the 
region raises questions about the magnitude and distribution—across countries and sectors—of 
the potential benefits of closer regional economic cooperation, its costs and constraints, and 
desirable  policies  to  maximize  net  benefits.  Numerous  studies  have  been  undertaken  on 
cooperation within subregions, especially in East Asia. However, research on the implications of 
economic cooperation between subregions within Asia is relatively scarce. Such research is 
necessary to inform policymakers about the types and sequence of policies to garner support 
for, and gain from, regional economic cooperation. This technical assistance (TA) is intended to 
contribute  to  this  effort  and  complements  other  analytical  work  in  the  area  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).5  The TA framework is in Appendix 1.6 
                                                 
1  For the purposes of this technical assistance (TA), East Asia is defined as the 10 members of the Association of 
Southeast Nations (ASEAN) plus People’s Republic of China (PRC), Japan, and Republic of Korea (Korea). South 
Asia  is  defined  as  seven  members  of  the  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  (SAARC): 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. 
2  In this paper, regional economic cooperation refers to policy measures jointly undertaken by a group of countries 
typically located within a geographic area to facilitate or enhance economic integration. Regional integration refers 
to actual integration of economies, which may be market-led, without formal cooperative initiatives (e.g., within East 
Asia until recently). The focus of this technical assistance is on cooperation among East and South Asian countries 
in trade of goods and services, and in infrastructure and trade facilitation. 
3  Within East Asia, some agreements in force are (i) ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), (ii) ASEAN-PRC Framework 
Agreement,  (iii)  Japan-Singapore  Economic  Agreement,  (iv)  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Economic 
Cooperation,  and  (v)  BIMP-EAGA  (Brunei-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines-East  ASEAN  Growth  Area).  Within 
South Asia, agreements that are in force are (i) South Asia Free Trade Area (SAFTA), and (iii) South Asia 
Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  (SASEC),  as  well  as  bilateral  agreements  between  the  largest 
economy─India─and Bhutan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. 
4  BIMSTEC comprises Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. 
5  ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for a Study on Monetary and Financial Cooperation in East Asia. Manila (TA 
6000-REG, for $500,000, approved on 2 October); ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for High-level Conference on 
Asia’s Economic Cooperation and Integration. Manila (TA 6172-REG, for $150,000 approved on 13 May); and 
ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Long-Term Scenarios for Asian Growth and Trade, 2005–2020. Manila (TA 
6205-REG, for $300,000, approved on 6 December).

2   
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Over the past decade, East Asia (excluding Japan) and South Asia were two of the 
fastest growing subregions in the world with annual average growth rates of 6.9% and 5.8% 
respectively. In 2004, the two subregions, excluding Japan, accounted for 10%7 of total world 
output, compared with 23% for the Eurozone and 32.6% for countries in the North American 
Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).8 In spite of the rapid growth, however, economic integration 
between the two subregions has increased only modestly. For example, East Asia’s share in 
South Asia’s total trade decreased slightly to 20.2% in 2004 from 20.8% in 1994, although it 
increased from a low of 17.8% in 2000 as East Asian countries recovered from the 1997 
financial crisis. South Asia’s share in East Asia’s total trade rose only modestly to 1.6% in 2004 
from 1.3% in 1994.9 The scope for enhanced investment links between the two subregions also 
appears to be large. East Asia’s share of total foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows into South 
Asia has risen from 6.5% in 1990, but it remained relatively low at 12% in 2002.10 South Asia’s 
FDI  into  East  Asia  has  remained  negligible  during  the  same  period,  although  anecdotal 
evidence suggests that Indian companies’ investment in PRC is gradually increasing.11 The 
potential  for  sustaining  high  rates  of  growth  in  the  two  subregions  through  enhanced 
cooperation  and  integration  is  thus  large.  Much  of  the  integration  that  has  occurred  until 
recently—especially within East Asia—reflected unilateral reforms and multilateral liberalization 
within the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework.12 The spate of cooperation agreements 
in recent years suggests that countries perceive significant advantages to be gained from 
regional cooperation.  
 
5.  There are several potential benefits of closer economic cooperation between the two 
subregions.13 First, when cooperation leads to greater integration, the consequent expansion of 
the market for goods and services increases the scope for economies of scale and greater 
competition. Second, increased competition within the integrated region could lead producers 
outside the region to reduce their prices as well, lowering prices of imports to the region and 
improving its terms of trade. Third, a more integrated region could attract more FDI with its 
attendant benefits of technology and knowledge transfer, and higher productivity. Fourth, and 
perhaps  more  importantly,  regional  cooperation  agreements  enable  deeper  and  wider 
integration among member countries than what may be feasible within a multilateral framework. 
Cooperation on infrastructure and trade facilitation (e.g., transport, customs clearance, and 
product standards) and services (e.g., financial services and labor services) would likely lead to

6.  In order to achieve their aim of boosting productivity and growth, however, East and 
South Asian economies have to overcome a number of challenges. First, the potential for trade 
diversion and trade deflection has to be minimized.15 Preferential tariffs granted to member 
countries may lead to diversion of trade if imports are sourced from a regional supplier that may 
be less efficient than one outside the region. Differential tariffs against extra-regional imports by 
members could also lead to trade deflection as exporters outside the region attempt to enter the 
regional market through the member with the lowest external tariff. These problems are likely to 
be magnified with overlapping agreements where a country is party to more than one bilateral 
agreement, sometimes among the same group of countries.16 Both risks could be minimized by 
limiting the margin of preference to members versus nonmembers. Furthermore, rules of origin 
specified on extra-regional imports to minimize trade deflection should be nonrestrictive so that 
(i) they do not heighten uncertainty for trade and investment, and (ii) their administrative costs 
are manageable. Second, in some member countries, tariff revenues are a significant portion of 
fiscal revenues. The loss of tariff revenues from trade diversion may need to be accompanied 
by fiscal reforms. Third, integration may lead to changes in the pattern of production across 
countries and sectors. These changes could arise from differences in comparative advantage 
and  from  location-specific  clustering  effects.17  As  a  consequence,  benefits  from  regional 
integration may not be equitably distributed across countries and sectors.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The intended impact of the TA is to facilitate more effective economic cooperation and 
integration  between  developing  member  countries  in  East  and  South  Asia.  The  expected 
outcome of the TA is that public and private stakeholders have an in-depth understanding and 
appreciation of policy steps required for effective economic cooperation and integration between 
the two subregions. The TA would thus help developing member countries and ADB devise 
strategies for effective regional economic cooperation and integration, and support ADB’s role 
as a catalyst of regional cooperation.   
 
8.  The outcome will be supported by a set of outputs:  (i) an assessment of sectors with the 
potential for significant benefits from cooperation; (ii) specific policy options at the regional,

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  A study will be undertaken using a computable general equilibrium (CGE) model to 
estimate the potential benefits of enhanced integration between East and South Asia and the 
distribution of these benefits across countries and sectors.18 The CGE model will allow the 
estimation  of  the  potential  effects  of  trade  liberalization  among  members  under  various 
scenarios and point to policy options that could enhance integration. Although the results are 
sensitive to assumptions about key parameters incorporated in the model, it is a widely used 
tool in assessing the economic impact of different policies. 
 
10.  Three separate studies will discuss the current degree of integration among East and 
South  Asian  countries  in  each  of  the  three  areas:  (i)  merchandise  trade  and  investment, 
(ii) trade in services, and (iii) infrastructure and trade facilitation. They will assess the scope for 
cooperation and further integration in specific sectors within each area; and provide policy 
options  at  regional,  subregional,  and  country  levels.  The  analysis  will  incorporate  an 
assessment of current and proposed regional agreements in East and South Asia in these 
areas, as well as their compatibility with the WTO framework. Where relevant, the analyses will 
draw upon lessons from experience of regional cooperation in other regions. 
 
11.  In addition, six case studies will be prepared to provide further detail on all three areas of 
cooperation from the perspective of selected developing member countries or country groups. 
The case studies could include three economies each in East and South Asia, one of which may 
be a country grouping such as the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS). These studies will help 
identify constraints that may be faced by a developing member country, such as the fiscal 
impact from liberalization and/or the magnitude of adjustment required with the likely change in 
the pattern of production from greater integration. The case studies would thus be able to 
indicate feasible policy options to overcome constraints and smooth the transition to greater 
integration. The studies would also address, from the country’s perspective, the consistency of 
various existing or proposed regional agreements as well as their compatibility with the WTO 
framework. 
 
12.  The following key activities are planned for the TA: 
 
(i)  Select consultants to research topics and prepare reports. A principal (international) 
consultant will be selected from among those chosen for the four topical studies (on 
potential benefits and three areas) to coordinate the work of other consultants and 
consolidate the overall findings of the studies. 
(ii) Organize a TA inception workshop to (a) detail the scope of research for each of the 
first four studies on potential benefits and the three areas; (b) identify the scope of 
country  case  studies;  (c)  finalize  the  terms  of  reference  for  each  study,  and 
(d) develop a timetable for completion of the studies on potential benefits, and on the 
four topics, country case studies, and the final TA report.

Manila (TA 6205–REG, for $300,000, approved on 6 December) to avoid duplication of efforts. In estimating 
potential benefits, it will employ the CGE model developed under TA 6205–REG, as appropriate.

5
(iii) Organize a finalization workshop once all the draft studies and the final TA report are 
completed. This workshop will involve the participation of policymakers as well as 
private sector representatives in East and South Asia to discuss key findings of the 
research and recommend any revisions to be made to the draft reports. Based on 
the discussion at the workshop, the consultants for each study will revise the draft 
reports and the principal consultant will submit a final TA report to ADB. The final TA 
report will include a set of specific policy options to enhance economic cooperation 
and integration in East and South Asia. It will identify the measures that can be taken 
at regional, subregional, and country levels, at various intervals, to promote greater 
economic cooperation and integration among East and South Asian countries. 
(iv) The results from the final TA report will be presented at a senior policy seminar with 
high-level  officials  from  East  and  South  Asia,  and,  where  appropriate,  at  other 
meetings.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 and will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s TA funding program. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. Within ADB, the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI) will implement the TA in close collaboration with other concerned 
departments and offices. OREI staff will (i) facilitate the engagement of consultants required to 
conduct the studies, (ii) review the research output and its consistency with the consultants’ 
terms of reference, (iii) plan and coordinate two workshops and the senior policy seminar 
related to the TA, and (iv) help produce and disseminate the results of the TA.   
 
15.  The TA will require about 9 person-months of international consulting services provided 
by individual consultants: (i) 1 person-month each for the principal consultant, the study on 
services trade, and the case study on a group of countries (e.g., GMS); and (ii) 2 person-months 
each for the studies on potential benefits, merchandise trade, and infrastructure and trade 
facilitation. The TA will require 5 person-months of domestic consulting services provided by 
individual consultants for the country case studies. All the consultants will be engaged by ADB 
in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The outline terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
16.  The TA is expected to commence in January 2006 and be completed by June 2007.  
The inception workshop is planned tentatively for the first quarter of 2006, and a finalization 
workshop for the fourth quarter of 2006. A senior policy seminar is planned for the second 
quarter  of  2007.  The  inception  workshop  and  senior  policy  seminar  will  be  held  at  ADB 
Headquarters. The finalization workshop is planned to be held in Singapore. The TA report will 
be published as a book to be disseminated to relevant policymakers and members of the public. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
A Study on Economic Cooperation between East Asia and South Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Principal Consultant—Overall Coordinator for the Technical Assistance (1 person-
month, international) 
 
1.  The principal consultant will be one of the four consultants selected for studies in (B) 
through  (E).  In  consultation  with  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  (OREI),  the 
principal consultant will coordinate the work of the consultants responsible for the other studies, 
including reviewing the draft reports and suggesting revisions to ensure that the studies form a 
mutually consistent report. Based on the other studies, the principal consultant will prepare an 
integrated technical assistance (TA) report on regional economic cooperation and integration in 
East and South Asia. 
 
2.  Besides coordinating the work of the other consultants, the key responsibility of the 
principal consultant will be preparing the overview report, which will integrate the key findings of 
the other studies. Based on these studies, the overview report will:  
 
(i)  examine the adequacy of current initiatives for regional economic cooperation 
and integration between East and South Asia; 
(ii)  identify the scope to strengthen these initiatives; 
(iii)  recommend types of changes required at country and regional levels in the areas 
of merchandise trade and investment, trade in services, and infrastructure and 
trade facilitation ; 
(iv)  assess the feasibility of the recommended policies; 
(v)  classify the final recommendations into three broad categories: those that can be 
implemented over 3 years; those that can be implemented over 3–5 years; and 
those requiring more than 5 years for implementation; 
(vi)  evaluate the implications of enhanced regional cooperation and integration for 
the multilateral system; and 
(vii)  identify  and  analyze  any  other  issues  that  are  relevant  for  fulfilling  the  key 
objectives of the TA. 
 
B.  Consultant  for  the  Study  on  Potential  Benefits  of  Enhanced  Asian  Economic 
Cooperation—Simulation Results (2 person-months, international) 
 
3.  The  consultant  will  have  substantial  experience  in  development  and  application  of 
computable general equilibrium (CGE) models in the area of trade in developing countries, 
especially Asia. In consultation with OREI and the principal consultant for the TA, the consultant 
will: 
 
(i)  update the CGE model developed under RETA 62051 or other state-of-the-art 
model consistent with the objectives of the study; 
(ii)  outline the analytical framework for the model, including its assumptions and 
limitations; 
(iii)  develop policy scenarios and simulate their effects; 
(iv)  assess the distribution of the effects of various policy scenarios across different 
countries and sectors; and

C.  Consultant for the Study on Merchandise Trade (2 person-months, international) 
 
4.  The consultant will be an expert on trade and investment policy in developing countries, 
especially Asia. In consultation with OREI and the principal consultant for the TA, the consultant 
will: 
 
(i)  assess in detail the current degree of cooperation and integration of East and 
South Asia in specific sectors of merchandise trade; 
(ii)  provide  an  analytical  framework  and  rationale  for  regional  cooperation  and 
integration,  and  identify  factors  constraining  it.  Where  appropriate,  the 
methodology  should  include  quantitative  methods  and/or  draw  upon  the 
experience of other regions; 
(iii)  discuss some of the existing and proposed agreements for regional cooperation 
and integration and identify good practices, drawing upon the experience of other 
regions where relevant; 
(iv)  evaluate existing and proposed agreements and their potential to relieve the 
constraints identified in (ii); 
(v)  evaluate  the  implications  of  existing  and  proposed  arrangements  for  the 
multilateral system; and 
(vi)  list and discuss policy recommendations and their sequence to enhance effective 
cooperation and integration. Recommendations should include specific policies 
for selected sectors within merchandise trade.   
 
D.  Consultant for the Study on Services Trade (1 person-month, international) 
 
5.  The consultant will be an expert on trade and investment policy in developing countries, 
especially Asia. In consultation with OREI and the principal consultant for the TA, the consultant 
will: 
 
(i)  assess in detail the current degree of cooperation and integration of East and 
South Asia in specific services sectors; 
(ii)  provide  an  analytical  framework  and  rationale  for  regional  cooperation  and 
integration in services, and identify factors constraining it. Where appropriate, the 
methodology  should  include  quantitative  methods  and/or  draw  upon  the 
experience of other regions; 
(iii)  discuss some of the existing and proposed agreements for regional cooperation 
and  integration  in  services  and  identify  good  practices,  drawing  upon  the 
experience of other regions where relevant; 
(iv)  evaluate existing and proposed agreements and their potential to relieve the 
constraints identified in (ii); 
(v)  evaluate  the  implications  of  existing  and  proposed  arrangements  for  the 
multilateral system; and 
(vi)  list and discuss policy recommendations and their sequence to enhance effective 
cooperation  and  integration  in  services.  Recommendations  should  include 
specific  policies  for  selected  areas  within  services  (e.g.,  financial  services, 
tourism).

E.  Consultant for the Study on Infrastructure and Trade Facilitation (2 person-months, 
international) 
 
6.  The  consultant  will  be  an  expert  on  trade  and  infrastructure  policy  in  developing 
countries, especially Asia. In consultation with OREI and the principal consultant for the TA, the 
consultant will: 
 
(i)  assess in detail the current degree of cooperation of East and South Asia in 
specific  areas  within  infrastructure  and  trade  facilitation,  e.g.,  cross-border 
transport, transit, customs, etc; 
(ii)  provide  an  analytical  framework  and  rationale  for  regional  cooperation,  and 
identify  factors  constraining  it.  Where  appropriate,  the  methodology  should 
include quantitative methods and/or draw upon the experience of other regions; 
(iii)  discuss some of the existing and proposed agreements for regional cooperation 
in infrastructure and trade facilitation and identify good practices, drawing upon 
the experience of other regions where relevant; 
(iv)  evaluate existing and proposed agreements and their potential to relieve the 
constraints identified in (ii); 
(v)  evaluate  the  implications  of  existing  and  proposed  arrangements  for  the 
multilateral system; and 
(vi)  list and discuss policy recommendations and their sequence to enhance effective 
cooperation  in  infrastructure  and  trade  facilitation.  Recommendations  should 
include specific policies for selected areas within each topic (e.g., transport within 
infrastructure and customs clearance within trade facilitation). 
 
F.  Consultants for the Country Case Studies (5 person-months, domestic; 1 person-
month, international) 
 
7.  The consultants will be trade and investment policy experts from the respective country 
or group of countries in East and South Asia. In consultation with OREI and the principal 
consultant for the TA, the consultant for each case study will: 
 
(i)  assess the evolution of the country’s economic cooperation and integration with 
other countries; 
(ii)  assess the degree of economic cooperation and integration in each of the three 
areas of merchandise trade and investment, services trade, and infrastructure 
and trade facilitation; 
(iii)  prioritize the sectors within each area, where appropriate, in terms of benefits 
from further cooperation and integration; 
(iv)  identify country-specific constraints to cooperation in the prioritized sectors within 
each  of  the  three  areas,  including  reference  to  current  and  proposed 
agreements; 
(v)  evaluate  the  consistency  of  the  country’s  current  and  proposed  agreements 
among themselves and their compatibility with the multilateral system; and   
(vi)  list and discuss policy recommendations at the country level to enhance effective 
cooperation  and  integration  and  their  sequence.  Recommendations  should 
include  specific  policies  for  selected  areas  within  each  topic  (e.g.,  financial 
service  within  services  trade,  or  transport  within  infrastructure  and  trade 
facilitation).
